doc.title: EMBOSS

description.text: European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite

doc.reference: EMBOSS: The European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite (2000) Rice,P. Longden,I. and Bleasby, A. Trends in Genetics 16, (6) pp276--277

description.text: Finds neighbouring pairs of features in sequence(s)

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory
fieldset.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

xhtml:div.label:
Source of first feature?
By default any feature source in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature source you wish to allow. The source name is usually either the name of the program that detected the feature or it is the feature table (eg: EMBL) that the feature came from. The source may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one source, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene* | embl

Type of first feature?
By default every feature in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to be any feature type you wish to allow. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. The type may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one type, separate their names with the character '|', eg: *UTR | intron

Sense of first feature?
Any sense Forward sense Reverse sense
By default any feature sense is allowed. You can set this to match the required sense.

Minimum score of first feature?
If this is greater than or equal to the maximum score, then any score is allowed.

Maximum score of first feature?
If this is less than or equal to the maximum score, then any score is permitted.

Tag of first feature?
Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to allow. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

Value of first feature's tags?
Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to allow. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

Source of second feature?
By default any feature source in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature source you wish to allow. The source name is usually either the name of the program that detected the feature or it is the feature table (eg: EMBL) that the feature came from. The source may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one source, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene* | embl

Type of second feature?
By default every feature in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to be any feature type you wish to allow. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. The type may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one type, separate their names with the character '|', eg: *UTR | intron

Sense of second feature?
Any sense Forward sense Reverse sense
By default any feature sense is allowed. You can set this to match the required sense.

Minimum score of second feature?
If this is greater than or equal to the maximum score, then any score is allowed.

Maximum score of second feature?
If this is less than or equal to the maximum score, then any score is permitted.

Tag of second feature?
Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to allow. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

Value of second feature's tags?
Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to allow. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

Type of overlap required?
Any Overlap required No overlaps are allowed Overlap required but not within A must be all within b B must be all within a
This allows you to specify the allowed overlaps of the features A and B. You can allow any or no overlaps, specify that they must or must not overlap, that one must or must not be wholly enclosed within another feature.

The minimum distance between the features?
If this is greater or equal to 'maxrange', then no min or max range is specified

The maximum distance between the features?
If this is less than or equal to 'minrange', then no min or max range is specified

Positions from which to measure the distance?
From nearest ends From left ends From right ends From furthest ends
This allows you to specify the positions from which the allowed minimum or maximum distance between the features is measured

Sense of the features?
Any sense Same sense Opposite sense
This allows you to specify the required sense that the two features must be on. This is ignored (always 'Any') when looking at protein sequence features.

Order of the features?
Any Feature a then feature b Feature b then feature a
This allows you to specify the required order of the two features. The order is measured from the start positions of the features. This criterion is always applied despite the specified overlap type required.

Do you want the two features written out individually?
Yes No
If you set this to be true, then the two features themselves will be written out. If it is left as false, then a single feature will be written out covering the two features you found.

Name of the output new feature?
If you have specified that the pairs of features that are found should be reported as one feature in the ouput, then you can specify the 'type' name of the new feature here. By default every feature in the feature table is allowed. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. If you specify an invalid feature type name, then the default name 'misc_feature' is used.
Name of the report file
Choose the report output format Dasgff Dbmotif Diffseq Embl Excel Feattable Genbank Gff Listfile Motif Nametable Codata Regions Seqtable Simple Srs Swiss Table Tagseq

div.title: This parameter is mandatory
div.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

format.code: ("", " -sequence=" + str(value))[value is not None]

div.title: This parameter is mandatory

Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to allow. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

interface.label:
Tag of second feature?
Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to allow. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to allow. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

format.code: ("", " -bvalue=" + str(value))[value is not None]

comment.text: Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to allow. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

interface.label:
Value of second feature's tags?
Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to allow. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is allowed. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to allow. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to allow more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

velem.label: A must be all within b
B must be all within a

format.code: ("", " -overlap=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: This allows you to specify the allowed overlaps of the features A and B. You can allow any or no overlaps, specify that they must or must not overlap, that one must or must not be wholly enclosed within another feature.

interface.label:
Type of overlap required?
Any Overlap required No overlaps are allowed Overlap required but not within A must be all within b B must be all within a
This allows you to specify the allowed overlaps of the features A and B. You can allow any or no overlaps, specify that they must or must not overlap, that one must or must not be wholly enclosed within another feature.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This allows you to specify the allowed overlaps of the features A and B. You can allow any or no overlaps, specify that they must or must not overlap, that one must or must not be wholly enclosed within another feature.

parameter.name: e_minrange
parameter.prompt: The minimum distance between the features

format.code: ("", " -minrange=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: If this is greater or equal to 'maxrange', then no min or max range is specified

interface.label:
The minimum distance between the features?
If this is greater or equal to 'maxrange', then no min or max range is specified

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If this is greater or equal to 'maxrange', then no min or max range is specified

parameter.name: e_maxrange
parameter.prompt: The maximum distance between the features

format.code: ("", " -maxrange=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: If this is less than or equal to 'minrange', then no min or max range is specified

interface.label:
The maximum distance between the features?
If this is less than or equal to 'minrange', then no min or max range is specified

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If this is less than or equal to 'minrange', then no min or max range is specified

parameter.name: e_rangetype
parameter.prompt: Positions from which to measure the distance

format.code: ("", " -rangetype=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: This allows you to specify the positions from which the allowed minimum or maximum distance between the features is measured

interface.label:
Positions from which to measure the distance?
From nearest ends From left ends From right ends From furthest ends
This allows you to specify the positions from which the allowed minimum or maximum distance between the features is measured

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This allows you to specify the positions from which the allowed minimum or maximum distance between the features is measured

format.code: ("", " -sense=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: This allows you to specify the required sense that the two features must be on. This is ignored (always 'Any') when looking at protein sequence features.

interface.label:
Sense of the features?
Any sense Same sense Opposite sense
This allows you to specify the required sense that the two features must be on. This is ignored (always 'Any') when looking at protein sequence features.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This allows you to specify the required sense that the two features must be on. This is ignored (always 'Any') when looking at protein sequence features.

format.code: ("", " -order=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: This allows you to specify the required order of the two features. The order is measured from the start positions of the features. This criterion is always applied despite the specified overlap type required.

interface.label:
Order of the features?
Any Feature a then feature b Feature b then feature a
This allows you to specify the required order of the two features. The order is measured from the start positions of the features. This criterion is always applied despite the specified overlap type required.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This allows you to specify the required order of the two features. The order is measured from the start positions of the features. This criterion is always applied despite the specified overlap type required.

parameter.name: e_twoout
parameter.prompt: Do you want the two features written out individually

format.code: ("", " -twoout")[ bool(value) ]

comment.text: If you set this to be true, then the two features themselves will be written out. If it is left as false, then a single feature will be written out covering the two features you found.

interface.label:
Do you want the two features written out individually?
Yes No
If you set this to be true, then the two features themselves will be written out. If it is left as false, then a single feature will be written out covering the two features you found.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If you set this to be true, then the two features themselves will be written out. If it is left as false, then a single feature will be written out covering the two features you found.

parameter.name: e_typeout
parameter.prompt: Name of the output new feature

format.code: ("", " -typeout=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: If you have specified that the pairs of features that are found should be reported as one feature in the ouput, then you can specify the 'type' name of the new feature here. By default every feature in the feature table is allowed. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. If you specify an invalid feature type name, then the default name 'misc_feature' is used.

interface.label:
Name of the output new feature?
If you have specified that the pairs of features that are found should be reported as one feature in the ouput, then you can specify the 'type' name of the new feature here. By default every feature in the feature table is allowed. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. If you specify an invalid feature type name, then the default name 'misc_feature' is used.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If you have specified that the pairs of features that are found should be reported as one feature in the ouput, then you can specify the 'type' name of the new feature here. By default every feature in the feature table is allowed. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. If you specify an invalid feature type name, then the default name 'misc_feature' is used.

format.code: ("" , " -outfile=" + str(value))[value is not None]

interface.label: Name of the report file

format.code: ("", " -rformat=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

interface.label: Choose the report output format Dasgff Dbmotif Diffseq Embl Excel Feattable Genbank Gff Listfile Motif Nametable Codata Regions Seqtable Simple Srs Swiss Table Tagseq

format.code: " -auto -stdout"
